text: What is CodeQL?

options.text: A code analysis tool
A programming language
A text editor
A version control system

text: What does shifting left mean in the context of Security?

options.text: Adopting security practices early in the development cycle
Writing code in a language that is commonly used
Incorporating security practices right before hitting production
Writing code without worrying about security

text: What are Repository Security Advisories?

options.text: A private space where repository maintainers can discuss vulnerabilities and security issues within the codebase.
GitHub security experts that help GitHub Enterprise users with their security issues.
A list of security issues that are publicly available for anyone to see and stay away from.
It's a place to gather and publicly discuss security issues in the open source community.

text: Which tool helps you keep the repository dependencies up to date?

options.text: Dependabot
Security Advisories
CodeQL
GitHub Actions

text: Which of the following is a curated list of security vulnerabilities found in open source projects?

options.text: GitHub Advisory Database
CodeQL
Dependabot
GitHub Security Journal

text: Which of these GitHub security features are available for FREE for both public and private personal repositories? (Choose four.)

options.text: Security Policy
Security advisories
Dependabot alerts and security updates
Dependabot version updates
Dependabot code scanning
Dependabot secret scanning

explanation:
https://docs.github.com/en/code-security/getting-started/github-security-features

Dependabot is not a tool for code scanning, it is a tool for dependency management Dependabot is not a tool for secret scanning, it is a tool for dependency management Secret scanning is available for public repositories and for organizations with a GitHub Advanced Security license. It's not available for personal private repositories. Code scanning is available for public repositories and for organizations with a GitHub Advanced Security license. It's not available for personal private repositories.

text: Which of these best describes secret scanning?

options.text: Secret scanning scans your repository for secrets such as private keys or tokens.
Secret scanning scans your repository for potential code vulnerabilities that could expose secrets such as private keys or tokens.
Secret scanning is a tool for secure secret storage and management.
Secret scanning is a git hook that will scan your commits for secrets such as private keys or tokens before they are pushed to GitHub.

text: Which parts of the repository are scanned by secret scanning? (Choose two.)

options.text: Entire git history on all branches in the repository
Titles, descriptions and comments in open and closed historical issues
GitHub Repository secrets
GitHub Environment secrets
Entire git history on all protected branches in the repository

text: What's the purpose of the Secret scanning partner program?

options.text: Service Providers can partner with GitHub so that the format of their secrets can be recognized by GitHub secret scanning.
GitHub Partner program allows enterprises and organizations with GitHub Advanced Security license to use GitHub secret scanning to scan their repositories.
GitHub partners with external security companies to provide secret scanning for GitHub repositories.
It's a program where registered security professionals can in good faith report to GitHub any secrets they find in GitHub repositories and get paid rewards for it.

text: Public repositories owned by personal users as well as public repositories owned by organizations can use secret scanning for free.

options.text: True
False

text: How can you prevent commits containing cloud provider credentials from being pushed to GitHub?

options.text: Enable a secret scanning push protection rule for your repository or organization.
Include a .gitignore file in your repository that will ignore files containing secrets.
Create a GitHub Action that will scan your commits for secrets before they are pushed to GitHub.
Enable a branch protection rule for your repository.

text: Which of these is true about the GitHub secret scanning partner program? (Choose three.)

options.text: It is a program where service providers can provide GitHub with the regex patterns of secrets that they issue so GitHub secret scanning can recognize them.
When GitHub identifies a secret from a partnered service provider, it notifies the service provider about the leaked secret.
The partner can take actions upon receiving notification from GitHub about a leaked secret, such as revoking the secret and informing the owner of the compromised secret.
It grants the partner access to the secret GitHub scanning API so that the service provider can scan GitHub repositories for secrets that match their format.
GitHub has the ability to automatically revoke leaked secrets and notify the service provider that they have been invalidated by GitHub.

explanation:
https://docs.github.com/en/code-security/secret-scanning/secret-scanning-partner-program

GitHub is always responsible for running the secret scanning, not the partner. GitHub does not participate in the revocation of leaked secrets; the service provider has the option to do so.

text: How can you exclude certain directories or files from secret scanning?

options.text: By creating a secret_scanning.yml file and including paths that should not be scanned
It's not possible to exclude specific files and/or directories from being scanned. Once you enable secret scanning for a repository, all files and directories will be scanned.
Include these files in the .gitignore file
By creating a dependabot.yml file and including paths which should not be scanned

text: You have included some fake secrets in your test code and they have been picked up by GitHub's secret scanning. What can you do to tell GitHub that these are fake secrets used in tests and can be ignored by secret scanning? (Choose two.)

options.text: By creating a secret_scanning.yml file within which you declare paths where fake secrets are located, so scans will omit them
Close the Secret Scanning Alert with Used in tests close reason
In your test files, add a comment #gh_ignore: fake secret on the line where the fake secret is located.
By creating a .github/codeql.yml file within which you declare paths where fake secrets are located, so scans will omit them

explanation:
[Managing secret scanning alerts](https://docs.github.com/en/code-security/secret-scanning/managing-alerts-from-secret-scanning#managing-secret-scanning-alerts)
[Excluding directories from secret scanning alerts](https://docs.github.com/en/code-security/secret-scanning/configuring-secret-scanning-for-your-repositories#excluding-directories-from-secret-scanning-alerts-for-users)

text: You have accidentally committed your GitHub personal access token to a public repository. What actions should you take to prevent your account from being compromised?

options.text: Consider the token compromised and delete it immediately
Change the token's permissions to read-only
Overwrite the git history to mask the token
Check if this token is used in any of your applications, if so - delete it.

text: What is the behavior when a new secret pattern is added or updated in the GitHub secret scanning partner program?

options.text: GitHub will run a scan of all historical code content in public repositories with secret scanning enabled

GitHub will only scan for the new pattern in newly pushed commits in repositories with secret scanning enabled. If a secret of that pattern was already present in the repository, it will not be detected.
The GitHub partner has to deal with the historically leaked secrets and GitHub will only scan any new commits for the new pattern
GitHub will create an issue in all repositories with secret scanning enabled so the maintainers can check the repository for any secrets matching the new pattern

text: Who will be notified when a NEW secret is pushed and detected in a repository? (Choose five.)

options.text: Repository Administrators
Security Managers
Users with custom roles with read/write access
Organization owners and enterprise owners, but only if they are administrators of repositories where secrets were leaked
Commit authors
Everyone with write access to the repository

text: When GitHub runs a scan of all historical code in enterprise repositories what is the notification behavior? (Select two.)

options.text: GitHub notifies the enterprise owners and security managers, even if no secrets are found.
GitHub notifies Repository administrators, security managers, and users with custom roles with read/write access whenever a secret is detected in a repository.
GitHub notifies the enterprise owners and security managers, only if it detects exposed secrets.
GitHub notifies the commit authors of the commits that contain exposed secrets.

text: Does GitHub use the same set of secret scanning patterns for both user alerts and push protection alerts?

options.text: No, these are different sets of secret patterns
Yes, its the same set of secret patterns

explanation:
https://docs.github.com/en/code-security/secret-scanning/secret-scanning-patterns#about-secret-scanning-patterns

There are three different sets of secret scanning patterns. They overlap but are not the same.

text: What are the three different sets of secret scanning patterns that GitHub maintains? (Select three.)

options.text: Partner patterns
User alert patterns
Push protection patterns
Enterprise alert patterns
Open source alert patterns
Cloud provider patterns

text: Multiple public repositories that you are contributing to do not have secret scanning push protection option enabled. What can you do to protect yourself from accidentally pushing secrets to these repositories?

options.text: Enable Push protection for yourself, in your personal GitHub account settings
Download the GitHub push protection web plugin
It's not possible, push protection has to be enabled on any of repository, organization or enterprise level
Add the files containing secrets to .gitignore file in all of the repositories

text: Your company has internal secrets that should not be pushed to GitHub repositories. The pattern of these secrets is not known by GitHub and therefore is not detected by secret scanning. What can companies do to protect their developers from accidentally pushing these secrets to repositories in their GitHub Organization?

options.text: Define regex patterns for these secrets and enable custom patterns for secret scanning for the organization.
The company should join the GitHub partner program so the pattern of the companies secrets is recognized.
Define custom GitHub Actions workflows for repositories in the organization that will scan for these secrets.
In all repositories include secret_scanning.yml file which will define these custom secrets that should be scanned for.

explanation:
https://docs.github.com/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-security/secret-scanning/defining-custom-patterns-for-secret-scanning#defining-a-custom-pattern-for-an-organization

GitHub partner program is meant for service providers which distribute secrets outside of their organization (e.g cloud providers). It's not meant for internal secrets of a single organization. `secret_scanning.yml` file that can be used to disable secret scanning for specific files or directories.

text: What information do Dependabot alerts provide?

options.text: Dependabot alerts tell you that your repository uses a package that is insecure.
Dependabot alerts tell you that your repository is being used by other public repositories.
Dependabot alerts tell you that your repository uses an untested version of a package.
Dependabot alerts tell you that your repository uses an outdated version of a package

explanation:
https://docs.github.com/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-alerts/about-dependabot-alerts

Dependabot does that with version updates, but not with alerts.

text: What is the GitHub dependency graph?

options.text: It is a representation of a repository's dependencies and dependents.
There is no such thing as the GitHub dependency graph.
It is a tool that automatically proposes version updates to dependencies in a repository.
It is a GitHub maintained list of known vulnerabilities in open source software packages.

text: Is GitHub dependency graph available for free to all repositories?

options.text: Yes, it's available for free for all repositories.
No, it's available for free for public repositories only. Private repositories can use it if they have the GitHub Advanced Security license.

text: How does GitHub Dependency graph know what dependencies your project is using? (Choose two.)

options.text: GitHub derives dependencies automatically from manifests and lock files committed to the repository
Dependencies can be manually added using the Dependency submission API
GitHub scans the repository code for import statements of external packages
It's required to add a GitHub Actions workflow that uses the official actions/dependency-graph GitHub Action to add dependencies to the graph whenever a new commit is pushed to the repository

text: When will the GitHub Dependency graph for your repository be updated? (Choose two.)

options.text: When anyone pushes a change to the repository of one of your dependencies.
When you push a commit to the repository's default branch, only if that changes or adds a supported manifest/lockfile.
When you push any commit to the repository's default branch.
When your repository publishes a new release.
When your repository publishes a new git tag.
When the GitHub Actions workflow that uses the actions/dependency-graph GitHub Action is triggered.

text: In what format can you export the GitHub Dependency graph of your repository?

options.text: SPDX
YAML
JSON
XML
CSV

text: Can your repository use Dependency Graph without using Dependabot Alerts?

options.text: Yes
No

explanation:
https://docs.github.com/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/understanding-your-software-supply-chain/about-the-dependency-graph#using-the-dependency-graph

You can use Dependency Graph without using Dependabot Alerts. However you can't use Dependabot Alerts with Dependency Graph disabled.

text: Which feature is a pre-requisite for using Dependabot Alerts on a repository?

options.text: Dependency graph
Dependency review
Dependency security updates
Dependency version updates

text: Which of these statements about Dependabot Alerts are true? (Choose three.)

options.text: They partially rely on the GitHub Advisory Database
To enable Dependabot Alerts you first need to have Dependency Graph enabled on your repository
When GitHub identifies a vulnerable dependency, they generate a Dependabot alert and display it on the Security tab for the repository
Dependabot Alerts are enabled by default for all repositories
Dependabot Alerts are enabled by default for all public repositories
Dependabot alerts tell you that your repository uses an outdated version of a package

text: What are the primary benefits of the Security Overview feature in GitHub?

options.text: Centralized view of security alerts and policy management in an organization
Automatic code review for every push
Real-time threat detection
Automated dependency updates

text: What is CodeQL?

options.text: A code analysis engine developed by GitHub
A new programming language for security analysis
A database used to store code scanning results
A third-party tool for static code analysis

text: What do Dependabot alerts indicate in GitHub?

options.text: The presence of a vulnerable dependency or malware in your repository
Outdated dependencies that need to be updated
Errors in dependency configuration files
Conflicts between different dependencies

text: What is the purpose of code scanning in GitHub?

options.text: To identify vulnerabilities and errors in code
To check code formatting and style
To review pull requests automatically
To synchronize code with production servers

text: Is secret scanning available for both public and private repositories on GitHub?

options.text: Yes, but for private repositories, it requires a license for GitHub Advanced Security
Yes, with no additional requirements
No, it is only available for public repositories
No, it is only available for private repositories

text: What does the default CodeQL analysis setup in GitHub do?

options.text: Automatically chooses languages to analyze, query suite to run, and events that trigger scans
Manually requires users to specify languages and queries for each scan
Scans code only on a monthly basis
Requires separate installation of third-party scanning tools

text: What is the main purpose of using the CodeQL CLI?

options.text: To generate a database representation of a codebase, a CodeQL database
To manage repository settings and permissions
To schedule regular maintenance tasks in a repository
To automatically merge pull requests

text: Which of the following languages is NOT supported by CodeQL for code scanning?

options.text: PHP
JavaScript/TypeScript
C/C++
Python

text: How does CodeQL analyze code in GitHub?

options.text: It generates a CodeQL database and runs queries to identify problems, displaying results as code scanning alerts
It uses machine learning to predict potential vulnerabilities based on past commits
It performs manual code reviews submitted by GitHub community members
It relies solely on third-party tools for code analysis

text: How can CodeQL be used in an external CI system together with GitHub repositories?

options.text: Run CodeQL CLI in the external CI system to scan code and upload the results to the GitHub repository
CodeQL cannot be used in external CI systems; it is exclusive to GitHub Actions
Upload source code to GitHub for analysis and then download results for use in the CI system
Manually run CodeQL locally and email the results to the GitHub repository administrators

text: Which of these statements isn't true about secret scanning on GitHub?

options.text: Secret scanning is a tool for secure secret storage and management.
Secret scanning will scan your entire Git history on all branches present in your GitHub repository for secrets.
Secret scanning will scan titles, descriptions, and comments, in open and closed historical issues for secrets.
Secret scanning can prevent supported secrets from being pushed into your enterprise, organization, or repository.

text: Which top-level keys are required in the dependabot.yml file?

options.text: version and updates
version and package-ecosystem
assignees and directory
updates and directory

text: Which GitHub Action can be used to upload a third-party SARIF file?

options.text: github/codeql-action/upload-sarif
codeql-upload-sarif
github/codeql-action
actions/upload-sarif

text: Which tool can be used in a third-party CI system to upload code analysis results to GitHub?

options.text: CodeQL CLI
CodeQL API
GitHub Actions github/codeql-action
GitHub CLI

text: What is required for a CI server to upload SARIF results to GitHub?

options.text: A GitHub App or personal access token with security_events write permission.
A direct connection to the GitHub Advisory Database.
Administrator access to the GitHub repository.
A special plugin installed in the CI system.

text: What happens when a second SARIF results file is uploaded to GitHub for a single commit?

options.text: It replaces the original set of data.
It appends the results to the existing file.
It creates a new branch in the repository
It is ignored by GitHub.

text: How can users exclude specific directories from secret scanning alerts on GitHub?

options.text: By configuring a secret_scanning.yml file, under the .github path in the repository.
Through the repository's Security tab, in the Secret scanning menu.
Through the repository's Settings tab, in the Code security and analysis menu.
By editing the repository's README.md file.

text: Which key should be used in a secret_scanning.yml file to exclude directories from secret scanning alerts in GitHub?

options.text: paths-ignore:
paths-exclude:
ignore-directories
exclude-paths:

text: What is the maximum number of custom patterns that can be defined for secret scanning on GitHub?

options.text: 500 for organizations/enterprises and 100 for repositories.
100 for organizations/enterprises and 500 for repositories.
100 for organizations, enterprises and repositories.
There's no limit to the number of custom patterns you can define for secret scanning in GitHub.

text: Fill in the blank: GitHub __________ is a feature that you can use to analyze code in a GitHub repository to find security vulnerabilities and coding errors.

options.text: Code Scanning
Dependency Graph
Security Advisories
Vulnerability Detection

text: Which GitHub Advanced Security feature allows you to find, triage, and prioritize fixes for new and existing problems in your code?

options.text: Code scanning
Dependabot alerts
Security policies
Security advisories

text: How can you enable code scanning for a repository?

options.text: Go to the security tab of the repository settings and enable code scanning with default or advanced setup.
Go to your user settings and enable code scanning, you can choose to enable it for all or only selected repositories.
Add a .github/codeql.ymlconfiguration file to the repository.
Go to the security tab of the repository settings and answer a questionnaire about the repository contents. Based on the answers, GitHub will enable code scanning with the appropriate configuration.

text: How can you configure your GitHub repository to run CodeQL analysis on a schedule? (Choose two.)

options.text: By creating a GitHub Actions workflow with a schedule trigger. The workflow should leverage actions from the github/codeql-action repository.
By using the default CodeQL analysis setup.
By setting the codeql.trigger property in the repository settings to schedule.
By adding a schedule property to the .github/codeql.yml configuration file.
By raising a request with GitHub support to enable scheduled CodeQL analysis for the repository.

text: An organization has recently started using CodeQL analysis for all pull requests on their repositories as well as running the analysis on an hourly schedule. Since then they are experiencing larger than usual GitHub Actions bills. What is the most likely cause of this?

options.text: Code scanning uses GitHub Actions and the organization is being billed for the additional usage.
The code scanning analysis is finding more issues than expected and is taking longer to complete.
Code scanning can only be run on a daily schedule and the organization is being billed for the additional usage.
There is no correlation between code scanning and GitHub Actions billing. The organization is being billed for other GitHub Actions workflows.

text: If you don't want to use GitHub Actions, you can run code scanning in an external CI system, then upload the results to GitHub.

options.text: True
False

text: When using a third party CI system to run code scanning, what GitHub tool do you need to analyze the codebase?

options.text: You don't specifically need a GitHub tool, any static analysis tool that can produce results in SARIF format will work.
You need to install the GitHub Code Scanning tool.
You need to install CodeQL CLI
You need to install GitHub CLI

text: When using GitHub Actions as your CI system and a third party tool to run code scanning, how can you upload the SARIF results to GitHub?

options.text: By using the github/codeql-action/upload-sarif GitHub Action
When using GitHub Actions the SARIF results are automatically uploaded to GitHub.
You can only use CodeQL when running code scanning in GitHub Actions. Third party code scanning tools are not supported.
By using the actions/upload-artifact GitHub Action

text: Can you use CodeQL analysis with third party CI systems?

options.text: Yes, you just need to use the CodeQL CLI
No, because it requires using the github/codeql-action GitHub Action

text: Which of these is true about code scanning? (Choose two.)

options.text: Code scanning helps finding insecure code patterns which can be missed by manual code review.
Code scanning can be integrated into the CI pipeline to find security issues early in the development process.
Code scanning is a replacement for manual code review.
Code scanning helps finding any leaked credentials in the codebase such as API keys or cloud credentials.
Code scanning scans your code to search for all dependencies and their versions to find any vulnerable dependencies.

text: When using CodeQL analysis in your GitHub Actions workflow, how often is the scan triggered?

options.text: Code scanning can be triggered for many different events that happen in the repository.
Code scanning is triggered on every push to the repository.
Code scanning is triggered on a configurable schedule
Code scanning can be triggered on a configurable schedule or on pull requests.

text:
What is the effect of adding the paths-ignore keyword to your code scanning GitHub Actions workflow? 
.github/workflows/codeql-analysis.yml

on:
  pull_request:
    branches: [main]
    paths-ignore:
      - '**/*.md'
      - '**/*.txt'

options.text: Avoiding unnecessary scans when files that are not relevant to the analysis are changed.
It tells CodeQL to omit all *.txt and *.md files from the analysis.
Preventing the CodeQL analysis from running on pull requests that change files with the specified extensions.
Pull request checks will ignore any CodeQL vulnerabilities that are found in *.txt and *.md files.

text: CodeQL scanning supports:

options.text: Both compiled and interpreted languages
Only compiled languages
Only interpreted languages
All programming languages

text: What are CodeQL queries used for?

options.text: CodeQL queries can be run against a CodeQL database to identify patterns that may indicate coding errors or security vulnerabilities.
CodeQL queries analyze your codebase and are used to create a CodeQL database.
CodeQL queries are used for code review purposes in GitHub.
CodeQL queries are text-based questions you can ask the CodeQL engine about your codebase.

text: What is QL?

options.text: QL is a query language that underlies CodeQL
QL stands for Quality Level and is a metric used by CodeQL
QL is a similar product to CodeQL but is used for scanning text files instead of code
QL is a npm package that is used by CodeQL to scan code

text: What is a CodeQL query suite?

options.text: CodeQL suite is a collections of CodeQL queries
CodeQL suite is a collection of CodeQL databases
CodeQL suite is a collection of CodeQL results
CodeQL suite is a collection of CodeQL supported languages

text: What are the different types of CodeQL packs? (Choose three.)

options.text: Query packs
Library packs
Model packs
Code packs
Language packs
Vulnerability packs

text: What is a CodeQL query pack?

options.text: It's a set of pre-compiled queries with all transitive dependencies such as libraries and models
It's a library used by CodeQL queries
It's a collection of CodeQL queries
It's a set of results that were generated in the process of analyzing a CodeQL database

text: What are the steps of CodeQL analysis workflow?

options.text: Creating a CodeQL database -
Running CodeQL queries -
Running CodeQL queries -
Creating a CodeQL database -

text: What is extraction in the context of CodeQL code analysis?

options.text: Extraction is the process of creating a relational representation of each source file in the codebase.
Extraction is the action of running CodeQL queries against a CodeQL database and extracting the results.
Extraction is the process of creating CodeQL queries specific to the codebase.
Extraction is the process of exporting data from a CodeQL database.

text: Which of these statements are true regarding running CodeQL analysis on codebases with multiple programming languages? (Choose two.)

options.text: CodeQL uses a different extractor for each programming language
CodeQL creates separate databases for each programming language
CodeQL creates one database for all programming languages in the codebase, as long as they are supported by CodeQL
CodeQL database schema is the same for each programming language

text: What are the differences when running CodeQL database creation for compiled and interpreted languages? (Choose two.)

options.text: For compiled languages, extraction works by monitoring the build process. All information is collected each time the compiler is invoked to process a source file.
For interpreted languages, the extractor runs directly on the source code.
For interpreted languages, extraction works by monitoring the build process. All information is collected each time the interpreter is invoked to process a source file.
For compiled languages, the extractor runs directly on the source code.
For compiled languages, the extractor runs on the executable file.
For interpreted languages, the extractor runs on the executable file.

text: Where can you see when the last CodeQL analysis was run when using the default code scanning setup?

options.text: In the code scanning tool status page
In repository insights
In the Dependabot tab
You can't see that information with the default setup

text: Which of the following statements about enabling CodeQL scanning default setup are true? (Choose three.)

options.text: You can enable default setup for all eligible repositories in an organization at once in the organization settings
GitHub Actions need to be enabled as a prerequisite
You can enable default setup on any repository, regardless of the contents of the repository
You can only enable default setup on repositories that contain at least one CodeQL-supported language
Default setup will scan the repository on a schedule that you can configure. For event based scanning, you need to configure a GitHub Action workflow
You can only use the default query suite with default CodeQL scanning setup

explanation:
https://docs.github.com/en/code-security/code-scanning/enabling-code-scanning/configuring-default-setup-for-code-scanning

If you enable default setup on a repository that does not include any CodeQL-supported languages, default setup will not run any scans Default setup includes scheduled scanning and pull request / push scanning on the default and protected branches

text: How can you customize your advanced CodeQL scanning setup with additional CodeQL query suites? (Choose two.)

options.text: By using a custom configuration file and defining additional queries there
By defining the customizations in the CodeQL analysis GitHub Actions workflow as input parameters to the github/codeql-action/init action
By using the CodeQL CLI with a custom configuration file to run the analysis
By defining the customizations in the Security / Code scanning repository settings
By using the github/codeql-customizations GitHub Action

text: When running CodeQL analysis in GitHub Actions, what Actions should you use? (Choose three.)

options.text: github/codeql-action/init
github/codeql-action/analyze
github/codeql-action/autobuild only for compiled programming languages
github/codeql-action/autobuild
github/codeql-action/init only for compiled programming languages
github/codeql-action/analyze only for interpreted programming languages

text: What is the simplest method to execute CodeQL analysis concurrently for each language in a multi-language repository using GitHub Actions?

options.text: By creating a languages matrix for the job and then reference it in the github/codeql-action/init action's languages input parameter
By calling the github/codeql-action/analyze action in separate steps for each language
By creating a separate workflow for each language
Define the parallelism in the github/codeql-action/analyze action

text: How can you use a custom CodeQL configuration file in a GitHub Actions workflow?

options.text: By explicitly providing the configuration file path in the config-file input parameter of the github/codeql-action/init action
By storing the configuration in .github/codeql/config-config.yml file. The github/codeql-action/init action will automatically detect the file and use it
By uploading that file in the Code Scanning section of the Security tab in the repository
By storing the configuration in .github/workflows/codeql-analysis.yml file. The github/codeql-action/init action will automatically detect the file and use it

text: Where can you specify the CodeQL queries to run in a GitHub Actions workflow? (Choose two.)

options.text: In the queries input parameter of the github/codeql-action/init action
In a CodeQL configuration YAML file
In the paths input parameter of the github/codeql-action/queries action
In the Code Scanning section of the Security tab in the repository
In the codeql field of the .github/settings.yml file

text: What is the purpose of the external-repository-token parameter in github/codeql-action/init GitHub Action?

options.text: It allows the action to access a private GitHub repository that contains configuration files, queries or packs that are required for the analysis.
It allows the action to upload the results of the analysis to a private GitHub repository.
It allows the action to access a private GitHub repository that contains the source code to be analyzed.
It allows the action to upload the generated CodeQL database to a private GitHub repository.

text: What CodeQL CLI command is used to create a CodeQL database?

options.text: codeql database create
gh codeql-database create
ql database generate
qlcli database create

text: What is the purpose of the codeql database analyze command in CodeQL CLI?

options.text: Analyzing a CodeQL database, producing results usually in the form of a SARIF file.
Analyzing a CodeQL database, producing results usually in the form of security advisories.
Analyzing the source code, producing a CodeQL database.
Analyzing a CodeQL database and uploading the results to GitHub.

explanation:
https://docs.github.com/en/code-security/codeql-cli/getting-started-with-the-codeql-cli/analyzing-your-code-with-codeql-queries#running-codeql-database-analyze

The results are not uploaded to GitHub, a separate command is used for that.

text: As part of your Jenkins CI pipeline you've successfully created and then analyzed a CodeQL database, therefore producing a SARIF file. How can you upload the SARIF file to GitHub? (Choose two.)

options.text: Using the codeql github upload-results command from CodeQL CLI
Using the GitHub REST API POST /repos/{owner}/{repo}/code-scanning/sarifs endpoint
Using the gh codeql upload-results command from GitHub CLI
By committing the SARIF file to the GitHub repository
Using the github/codeql-action/upload-sarif GitHub Action

explanation:
https://docs.github.com/en/code-security/code-scanning/integrating-with-code-scanning/uploading-a-sarif-file-to-github#about-sarif-file-uploads-for-code-scanning

You can't use GitHub Actions in Jenkins pipelines.

text: What details can you find on a code scanning alert page? (Choose three.)

options.text: Branches affected by the vulnerability
Highlighted vulnerable code
Severity of the vulnerability
Information how many times the vulnerability has been exploited
Assigned developer to fix the vulnerability
ID of the CodeQL database that was used to find the vulnerability

text: Which of these statements regarding viewing the results of a CodeQL analysis are true? (Choose two.)

options.text: You need write permission to view a summary of all the alerts for a repository in the Security tab.
Anyone with read permission for a repository can see code scanning annotations on pull requests.
You need write permission to view code scanning annotations on pull requests.
Anyone with read permissions for a repository can view code scanning alerts in the Security tab.
Only the repository owner can see the code scanning alerts in the Security tab.

text: When a CodeQL analysis GitHub Actions workflow detects a new vulnerability on a pull request, where can you find the information about that vulnerability?

options.text: Directly in the pull request in the form of a PR comment and a check failure
In the security tab of the repository
In the workflow run logs
The CodeQL analysis workflow will fail and produce an artifact with the results

text: When viewing a code scanning alert what is the Show paths option used for?

options.text: It will display the path through the code that leads to the issue causing the alert.
It's used for showing the paths to the CodeQL queries that were used to find the vulnerability
It will show recommendations on how to fix the vulnerability
It's used for showing the file path to the CodeQL database that was used to find the vulnerability

text: What does it mean to dismiss a code scanning alert?

options.text: Closing an alert that you don't think needs to be fixed
Closing the alert after fixing the vulnerability in the code

text: Which of these is NOT a valid approach one can take to reduce the time it takes for CodeQL analysis workflow to complete?

options.text: Run the analysis on every push event
Use runners with more CPU/RAM resources
Parallelize the analysis for multi-language codebases
Ignore irrelevant files and directories from the analysis
Reduce the number of queries that are run

text: What is the purpose of defining a SARIF category?

options.text: Use the category to distinguish between multiple analyses for the same tool or commit, but performed on different languages or different parts of the code.
Use the category to distinguish files that have been analyzed from files that have not been analyzed.
Use the category to distinguish files that contain vulnerabilities from files that do not contain vulnerabilities.
Use a different category for each file that has been analyzed to easily track back the vulnerabilities to the files that contain them.

text: How can you enable GitHub Advanced Security features on GitHub Enterprise Server? (Choose two.)

options.text: In the Security tab of the Site admin management console
By connecting directly to the GitHub Enterprise Server instance through SSH and using the administrative shell ghe-config commands.
By requesting an upgrade from GitHub Support
By setting the github.advanced_security.enabled configuration option to true in the config.yml file in the /etc/github directory on the GitHub Enterprise Server instance.
By setting the github.advanced_security.enabled configuration option to true in the config.yml file in the .github repository.

text: How can you enable GitHub Advanced Security features for all repositories in an organization in GitHub Enterprise Cloud?

options.text: In Code security and analysis section of the organization settings
By connecting directly to the GitHub Enterprise Cloud instance through SSH and using the administrative shell ghe-config commands.
By requesting an upgrade from GitHub Support
In the Site admin page of your enterprise account

explanation:
https://docs.github.com/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/organizations/keeping-your-organization-secure/managing-security-settings-for-your-organization/managing-security-and-analysis-settings-for-your-organization#enabling-or-disabling-a-feature-for-all-existing-repositories

That is an option when using GitHub Enterprise Server

text: As a repository maintainer where should you put instructions on how to report a security vulnerability in your codebase?

options.text: In the SECURITY.md file
In the CONTRIBUTING.md file
In the README.md file
In the CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md file

text: What is a GitHub security policy?

options.text: It's a document that instructs users on how to responsibly report security vulnerabilities in a project. It's typically defined in a SECURITY.md file in a repository.
It's a tool for automatically fixing security vulnerabilities in your code.
It's a feature that allows you to encrypt your repository.
A GitHub security policy is a subscription service that provides antivirus protection for your projects.

text: How can you set a default security policy for all repositories in my-org GitHub Organization?

options.text: By creating a SECURITY.md file in the my-org/.github repository
By editing the security policy in the organization's Code Security and analysis settings
Default security policies can only be set by GitHub support
You can set a default security policy for all repositories in my-org GitHub Organization by adding a SECURITY.md file to each individual repository.

text: Which API endpoint can be used to retrieve a list of all Dependabot alerts for an enterprise?

options.text: GET /enterprises/{enterprise}/dependabot/alerts
GET /orgs/{org}/dependabot/alerts
GET /repos/{owner}/{repo}/dependabot/alerts
GET /github/{enterprise}/dependabot/alerts

explanation:
https://docs.github.com/en/rest/dependabot/alerts?apiVersion=2022-11-28#list-dependabot-alerts-for-an-enterprise

That is a correct endpoint for organization, but not for an enterprise That is a correct endpoint for a repository, but not for an enterprise

text: Which API endpoint can be used to retrieve a list of all secret scanning alerts for an organization?

options.text: GET /orgs/{org}/secret-scanning/alerts
GET /enterprises/{enterprise}/secret-scanning/alerts
GET /repos/{owner}/{repo}/secret-scanning/alerts
GET /github/{org}/secret-scanning/alerts

explanation:
https://docs.github.com/en/rest/secret-scanning/secret-scanning?apiVersion=2022-11-28#list-secret-scanning-alerts-for-an-organization

That is a correct endpoint for enterprise, but not for an organization That is a correct endpoint for a repository, but not for an organization

text: Which API endpoint can be used to retrieve a list of all code scanning alerts for a repository?

options.text: GET /repos/{owner}/{repo}/code-scanning/alerts
GET /orgs/{org}/{repo}/code-scanning/alerts
GET /{enterprise}/{org}/{repo}/code-scanning/alerts
GET /github/{repo}/code-scanning/alerts

text: Which of these statements best defines a vulnerable dependency?

options.text: A vulnerable dependency is dependency that a project relies on, which contains security flaws that could potentially be exploited, compromising the project's security.
A vulnerable dependency is dependency that a project relies on, which has not been updated in a long time.
A vulnerable dependency is dependency that a project relies on, which is not widely used or popular.
A vulnerable dependency is dependency that a project relies on, which is not verified by GitHub.

text: What are Dependabot security updates?

options.text: It's a Dependabot feature that automatically creates pull requests to update vulnerable dependencies in your repository.
It's a Dependabot feature that creates a list of vulnerable dependencies in your repository.
It's a Dependabot feature that creates alerts when a security vulnerability is detected in one of your dependencies.
It's a Dependabot feature that automatically creates pull requests to update dependencies in your repository when they release a new version.

explanation:
https://docs.github.com/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-security-updates/about-dependabot-security-updates

That's Dependabot alerts, Dependabot security updates are based on Dependabot alerts. That's Dependabot version updates

text: Dependabot Alerts are enabled by default on:

options.text: Dependabot Alerts are not enabled by default on any repositories.
Only public repositories.
All repositories.
Only private repositories.

explanation:
https://docs.github.com/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-alerts/about-dependabot-alerts#configuration-of-dependabot-alerts

GitHub detects vulnerable dependencies in public repositories and displays the dependency graph, but does not generate Dependabot alerts by default.

text: Who can enable Dependabot alerts on a repository?

options.text: Repository owners and people with admin access
Only the repository owner
Dependabot alerts are enabled on all repositories by GitHub and can't be disabled or enabled by any individual.
Dependabot alerts are enabled by adding a GitHub Action to the repository, so anyone with write access to the repository can enable them.

text: What's the lowest access level needed to see Dependabot alerts in a repository within an organization?

options.text: Write
Read
Maintain
Triage
Admin

text: To enable Dependabot Alerts on all repositories in an organization you should:

options.text: Go to the organization's Code security and analysis settings and enable Dependabot Alerts for all repositories at once.
Make all repositories in the organization private.
On all repositories in the organization - run the actions/enable-ghas GitHub Action with alerts parameter set to true
Create a script that will enable Dependabot Alerts on all repositories in the organization.

text: Which of these is a valid dependabot.yml configuration file?

options.text:
yaml 
    version: 2
    updates:
    - package-ecosystem: "npm"
        directory: "/"
        schedule:
          interval: "daily"

yaml 
    version: 2
    config:
    - directory: "/"
        schedule:
          interval: "daily"

yaml 
    version: 2
    updates:
    - package-ecosystem: "npm"
        directory: "/"
        schedule:
          interval: "everyday"

yaml 
    version: 2
    config:
    - package-ecosystem: "npm"
        directory: "/"
        schedule:
          interval: "daily"

github.com notification inbox
GitHub Mobile
GitHub CLI
Email

Warnings are displayed as callbacks when you push to repositories with any insecure dependencies

text: What are Dependabot auto-triage rules?

options.text: It's a feature that allows Dependabot to automatically dismiss Dependabot alerts that match certain criteria.
Auto-triage rules are defined in the dependabot.yml configuration file to specify which package managers should be used to scan your project for vulnerabilities.
Dependabot auto-triage rules are used for automatically deleting old dependencies in your project.
Auto triage rules define how often Dependabot should scan your project for vulnerabilities.

text: How can you automate dismissing low severity Dependabot alerts?

options.text: By using Dependabot's auto-triage rules.
By setting the severity field in dependabot.yml file to high
By removing all dependencies that cause low severity alerts
By setting the dismiss-severity field in dependabot.yml file to low

text: To enable Dependabot security updates on all repositories in an organization you should:

options.text: Go to the organization's Code security and analysis settings and enable Dependabot Security Updates for all repositories at once.
Make all repositories in the organization private.
Run the actions/enable-ghas GitHub Action with security-updates parameter set to true on all repositories in the organization.
Create a script that will enable Dependabot Security Updates on all repositories in the organization.

text: The tool that checks if a pull request introduces any dependencies with security vulnerabilities is called:

options.text: Dependency Review
Dependabot Alerts
Dependabot Security Updates
Dependabot Version Updates

text: You need GitHub Actions enabled for

options.text: Dependency Review
Dependabot Security Updates
Dependabot Version Updates
All of these
None of these

explanation:
https://docs.github.com/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-version-updates/about-dependabot-version-updates#about-dependabot-version-updates

GitHub Actions is not required for Dependabot version updates and Dependabot security updates to run on GitHub. However, pull requests opened by Dependabot can trigger workflows that run actions. Dependency review uses `actions/dependency-review-action` GitHub Action

Cybersecurity Verification Entity

text: What does CWE stand for?

Cybersecurity Weakness Enumeration
